subject: Re: [junit] Am I headed in the right direction here?
msgSnippet: There are two ways (that I know of) to do this. 1) Create your own button to pass to JOptionPane (using the options parameter). 2) Use the AccessibleContext
messageBody:
There are two ways (that I know of) to do this.

1) Create your own button to pass to JOptionPane (using the options
parameter).

2) Use the AccessibleContext (getAccessibleContext()) to walk through the
children and find the button you need. I could have sworn that the
identifier you need was actually documented somewhere or stored in a
static variable, but I cannot for the life of me find it right now.

On Wed, 26 Dec 2001, lchalupa wrote:

> New to Junit.
> Please give advice on my approach to testing a gui.
> In the gui, my target method displays an instance of jOptionPane class
> to confirm a selection the user has just made. In my junit test
> method, I want to be able to select and close the button on
> jOptionPane after it has been displayed.
>
> I am not sure how to do this. I have done this on dialogs that I have
> created myself by looking up the button and using doClick(). Seems to
> work just fine.
>
> So, do I use the same approach on jOptionPane? I assume I would look
> up the identifier of the button in the source and refer to it in the
> test method? Or am I missing a more direct approach to the problem?
>
> In short, I am not sure how to test a jOption Pane using Junit.
>
> Am I on the right track?
>
> Thanks.
>
